author: Mitch4406,"Unless Ms. Marie- Turner has a time machine she can't know that it doesn't work. Give her some space in the NYT in Sept. 2016 and maybe she can make that argument. But not now. It's to soon to know. The republicans are expending considerable resources, including spending millions in attack ads and having republican governors purposely scuttle there own health care exchanges, just to be able to say they went against the President. There going to have to do better than that. Would it kill them to have some fresh ideas for a change. She claims that it's 2,800 pages long when in fact it's 906 pages long. Check it out. The law, in my opinion, is good just because of the fact that it prevents the denial of insurance coverage based on a ""pre-existing condition. We should consider all the people who, before Obama Care, were forced to burn through there life savings because an insurance company ruled there ailment was a pre-existing Entropic,"I would tend to agree: Poll results (no matter how ill formed the poll questions) create a public narrative that exists outside of any rigorous definition of reality. This is very much like the artificial Red State / Blue State divide, when in fact most states are clearly purple. But polls tell us Texas is full of tea party nuts, and Massachusetts the lair of well meaning but totally impractical socialists and Harvard pontificators. And ne'er the twain shall meet. This is, of course, a dangerous way to conduct public dialogue, and I lay a lot of the blame on the press, which refuses to call the idiocy of some of these polls out. The fourth estate needs to step back and find some voices of reason.",pollings,A3263-P,pollings,0,1,481,16803626,"[[""would"", ""tend"", ""agree"", ""poll"", ""results"", ""matter"", ""ill"", Jim L,"I watch enough cooking competitions (on TV) to realize that 4 chefs at a table will not all agree as to the quality and complexity of the seasoning upon the palate. Now add 2 or three courses, and remove the trained palates from diners who may be there for reasons other than the chef's concoction, and you may realize that salt and pepper belong on the table to satisfy the the varying palates of those paying to dine. I like a bit of salt on my salad, especially on tomatoes or the bread which is put on the table. At home in the shaker, we use salt that has the lowest amount of sodium (approx. 280mg per serving) and we have a grinder as well. I rarely add salt without taking a bite first. I have also had dishes where I wish i could remove salt from a dish. Leave it on the table. Those with health concerns and have minimal will power, ask to have it removed from the table.",a place at the table,A1772-P,a place at the table,1,1,13653,9948974,"[[""watch"", ""enough"", Jodi Anderson,"With the costs of education FAR outpacing inflation, I wonder what these unpaid interns have to do to keep their heads above water? (Those who aren't lucky/rich enough to have parental support, that is). Of course, the price inflation of education accident. It's due to the government policy of underfunding public education. Coming from a disadvantaged background, I was simply unable afford to take on unpaid work during and after college, regardless of how much it might have helped my future career to do so. Thus I was at a disadvantage compared to peers at my college. This doesn't really sound like a level playing field, does it??? One additional point: The emphasis on internship experience on resumes allows employers an easy way to ascertain which candidates are likely to come from wealthier backgrounds...making it easier for employees to discriminate in terms of social class and race (since certain races are more likely to be represented in the disadvantaged group). Not fair. And we wonder why there are no jobs out there? Employers are filling lots of them for free.",college students,A455-P,college students,1,1,9641,5445428,"[[""costs"", ""education"", ""far"", ""outpacing"", ""inflation"", ""wonder"", ""unpaid"", Pierre Lehu,"I find most restaurant food too salty. I know this not so much from the taste but the way my body reacts afterwards. Sequel,"I prefer to know how many people are responding to a Times article in a manner that would please Nazi's and racists and homophobes. I prefer to know why they think such horrifying things, and how deeply they feel about it. And I really appreciate seeing how people hasten to tell them they are seriously wrong. I don't feel that I am in any danger of absorbing horrific ideas simply by hearing them. I would call that a bogus social theory. The converse of the idea that social engineering of permissible ideas is a good thing, is that people respond better if only exposed to approved ideas. That's just as bad.",comment sections,A2752-P,comment sections,1,1,2766,18247485,"[[""prefer"", ""know"", ""many"", ""people"", ""responding"", ""times"", ""article"", ""manner"", ""would"", ""please"", ""nazi"", ""'s"", ""racists"", ""homophobes""], [""prefer"", ""know"", ""think"", ""horrifying"", ""things"", ""deeply"", ""feel""], [""really"", ""appreciate"", ""seeing"", ""people"", ""hasten"", ""tell"", ""seriously"", ""wrong""], [""n't"", ""feel"", ""danger"", ""absorbing"", ""horrific"", ""ideas"", ""simply"", ""hearing""], [""would"", ""call"", ""bogus"", ""social"", ""theory""], [""converse"", ""idea"", ""social"", ""engineering"", ""permissible"", ""ideas"", ""good"", ""thing"", ""people"", ""respond"", ""better"", ""exposed"", ""approved"", ""ideas""], [""'s"", ""bad""]]","[[""VBP"", ""VB"", ""JJ"", ""NNS"", ""VBG"", ""NNP"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""MD"", ""VB"", ""NNP"", ""POS"", ""NNS"", ""NNS""], [""VBP"", ""VB"", ""VBP"", ""JJ"", ""NNS"", ""RB"", ""VBP""], [""RB"", ""VBP"", ""VBG"", ""NNS"", ""VB"", ""VB"", ""RB"", ""JJ""], [""RB"", ""VB"", ""NN"", ""VBG"", ""JJ"", ""NNS"", ""RB"", ""VBG""], [""MD"", ""VB"", ""JJ"", ""JJ"", ""NN""], [""NN"", ""NN"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""JJ"", ""NNS"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""NNS"", ""VBP"", ""RBR"", ""VBN"", ""VBN"", ""NNS""], [""VBZ"", ""JJ""]]",prefer know many people responding times article manner would please nazi 's racists homophobes. prefer know think horrifying things deeply feel. really appreciate seeing people hasten tell seriously wrong. n't feel danger absorbing horrific ideas simply hearing. would call bogus social theory. converse idea social engineering permissible ideas good thing people respond better exposed approved ideas. Rick,"I'm confused. When, in the process of procreation, does a parent automatically become an expect in medical or educational fields? ManhattanWilliam,"I think the concept of rating professors online (like just about any other form of public ratings) is ludicrous. To think that students attending a college where they are to be judged by a professor and given a grade for a class should be taken as fair and impartial in rating that professor's performance makes ZERO sense. Even worse, of course, are people who go out to eat and suddenly find themselves qualified to write for Gourmet Magazine. I read these reviews occasionally but NEVER take them seriously. Still, complaining will do nothing to stop this from occurring. Such are the times we live in and nothing is going to turn back the clock HOWEVER I, for one, think the concept is pretty repulsive and anyone or any institution that takes these ratings seriously is, by my definition, a person not to be taken seriously.",rate professors,A4739-P,rate professors,0,1,1477,16969541,"[[""think"", ""concept"", ""rating"", ""professors"", ""online"", ""like"", ""form"", Earthling,"According to the Centers for Disease Control, childhood obesity has more than doubled in children and quadrupled in adolescents in the past 30 years. The percentage of children aged 6-11 years in the United States who were obese increased from 7% in 1980 to nearly 18% in 2012. Similarly, the percentage of adolescents aged 12-19 years who were obese increased from 5% to nearly 21% over the same period. Now, more than one-third of American children and adolescents are overweight or obese. The obesity epidemic is linked to screen time, to kids sitting on their butts looking at screens all day, to the lack of outdoor activity and exercise. Mind and body are interactive systems and without a healthy body, there can be no healthy mind. How many yougn people these days are depressed, or hyperactive, or otherwise suffering from some mental disorder --- and how many would benefit from fresh air and exercise and time in the natural world? Mr. Bergman does not even begin to address childhood and adolescent obesity in his screed based only on personal anecdote.",internet addiction,A5230-P,internet John Gunther,"Separating internships as a special class of poorly paid work seems almost pointless. If MacDonald's can't employ a cashier who's willing to work for less than minimum wage (or for free), why can ABC do it for an intern? The only reason for an exception would be if the intern is there for true training purposes and not for the employer's immediate benefit. Clearly, most interns are there to supply grunt labor, whether or not they actually get a chance to show their stuff. Also, the kind of large corporations who hire rafts of interns can certainly afford to pay them minimum wage to escape all legal scrutiny. These firms could still take comfort in knowing that minimum wage isn't nearly enough to live on.",unpaid intenship,A446-P,unpaid intenship,0,1,3438,5449542,"[[""separating"", ""internships"", Gevalt,"Yesterday in the UN there were speeches and debates about recognizing Palestine as a member country. This is an entity that has no attributes of a country: no demarcated territory, no army, no domination of its land, no constitution, no postal system, etc. Taiwan is a country. It has been for many years. We need to have Taiwan in the UN. And it was in the UN. Except it was booted out because of the bullying of Communist China. The only time this has ever happened was with Taiwan. Taiwan, not Palestine, needs to be recognized for what it is, a true, independent, democratic state. Gevalt,"Yesterday in the UN there were speeches and debates about recognizing Palestine as a member country. This is an entity that has no attributes of a country: no demarcated territory, no army, no domination of its land, no constitution, no postal system, etc. Taiwan is a country. It has been for many years. We need to have Taiwan in the UN. And it was in the UN. Except it was booted out because of the bullying of Communist China. The only time this has ever happened was with Taiwan. Taiwan, not Palestine, needs to be recognized for what it is, a true, independent, democratic state. The US and the rest of the democratic world should immediately recognize Taiwan and honor all treaties with it.",arms,A5080-P,if it is a country,2,2,1794,4581192,"[[""yesterday"", ""un"", ""speeches"", ""debates"", ""recognizing"", ""palestine"", ""member"", ""country""], [""entity"", ""attributes"", ""country"", ""demarcated"", ""territory"", ""army"", ""domination"", ""land"", ""constitution"", ""postal"", ""system"", ""etc""], [""taiwan"", ""country""], [""many"", ""years""], [""need"", ""taiwan"", ""un""], [""un""], [""except"", ""booted"", ""bullying"", ""communist"", ""china""], [""time"", ""ever"", ""happened"", ""taiwan""], [""taiwan"", ""palestine"", ""needs"", ""recognized"", ""true"", ""independent"", ""democratic"", ""state""], [""us"", ""rest"", ""democratic"", ""world"", ""immediately"", ""recognize"", ""taiwan"", ""honor"", ""treaties""]]","[[""NN"", ""NNP"", ""NNS"", ""NNS"", ""VBG"", ""NNP"", ""NN"", ""NN""], [""NN"", ""NNS"", ""NN"", ""VBN"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""FW""], [""NNP"", ""NN""], [""JJ"", ""NNS""], [""VBP"", ""NNP"", ""NNP""], [""NNP""], [""IN"", ""VBN"", ""NN"", ""NNP"", ""NNP""], [""NN"", ""RB"", ""VBN"", ""NNP""], [""NNP"", ""NNP"", ""VBZ"", ""VBN"", ""JJ"", ""JJ"", ""JJ"", ""NN""], [""NNP"", ""NN"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""RB"", ""VB"", ""NNP"", ""VB"", ""NNS""]]",yesterday un speeches debates recognizing palestine member country. entity attributes country demarcated territory army domination land constitution postal system etc. taiwan country. many years. need taiwan un. un. except booted bullying communist china. time ever happened taiwan. taiwan palestine needs recognized true independent democratic state. us rest democratic world immediately recognize taiwan honor treaties,"[""country""]",country,1,1;;;

JMATA,"Not subject to the jurisdiction of the United States suggests, for example, people born in embassies, which are extraterritorial. Jurisdiction in this context is a territorial concept: i.e. where the laws can be applied. ShowMe,"We definitely need libraries!! It was my safe sanctuary when I was chased as a kid by bullies on my way home from school. We definitely need both printed books and Internet access, and digital books accessible from home, too. However, everyone cannot afford the digital devices so public access from the library is necessary. We would be wise to put a library within walking distance of every American, and keep the library open 24/7. The library is the most valuable resource for lifelong learning.",libraries,A1600-P,libraries,1,1,19261,7950152,"[[""definitely"", ""need"", ""libraries""], [""safe"", ""sanctuary"", ""chased"", ""kid"", ""bullies"", ""way"", ""home"", ""school""], [""definitely"", ""need"", ""printed"", ""books"", ""internet"", ""access"", ""digital"", ""books"", ""accessible"", ""home""], [""however"", ""everyone"", ""afford"", ""digital"", ""devices"", ""public"", ""access"", ""library"", ""necessary""], [""would"", ""wise"", ""put"", ""library"", ""within"", ""walking"", ""distance"", ""every"", ""american"", ""keep"", ""library"", ""open"", ""24/7""], [""library"", ""valuable"", ""resource"", ""lifelong"", ""learning""]]","[[""RB"", ""VBP"", ""NNS""], [""JJ"", ""NN"", ""VBN"", ""NN"", ""NNS"", ""NN"", ""RB"", ""NN""], [""RB"", ""VBP"", ""VBN"", ""NNS"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""JJ"", ""NNS"", ""JJ"", ""RB""], [""RB"", ""NN"", ""VB"", ""JJ"", ""NNS"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""JJ""], [""MD"", ""JJ"", ""VB"", ""NN"", ""IN"", ""VBG"", ""NN"", ""DT"", ""NNP"", ""VB"", ""NN"", ""JJ"", ""CD""], [""NN"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""JJ"", ""NN""]]",definitely need libraries. safe sanctuary chased kid bullies way home school. definitely need printed books internet access digital books accessible home. however everyone afford digital devices public access library necessary. would wise put library within walking distance every american keep library open 24/7. library valuable resource lifelong learning,"[""library""]",library,1,1;;;

Ginevra,"""The lawsuit against Hearst claims that unpaid internships exacerbate class divisions, because some people can afford to work free and others cannot. But the same could be said of almost any opportunity that allows students from wealthier backgrounds to enhance their human capital more effectively than students from less privileged backgrounds."" So....let me get this straight. You are suggesting that we unravel a century of progress in developing and enforcing fair labor and wage laws and protections for young workers, all because life isn't fair? Of course life isn't fair. Some individuals will always have more advantages than others. This does not give us license to actively make the playing field LESS level.",unpaid internship,A450-P,unpaid internship,0,1,11328,5447502,"[[""lawsuit"", ""hearst"", ""claims"", ""unpaid"", SouthernView,"Fletcher has got it exactly right. The best solution would be for both Elizabeth and Charles to abdicate and turn the Firm over to William and Kate. But since that will not happen, let's postpone until we're left with no choice the ascension of Charles--and even worse, Camilla. The thought of boring, stuffed-shirt Charles as king for decades is bad enough, but having Camilla shoved front and center would be a nightmare come true, even without the formal title of queen. Imagine-year after year of pictures of the two puttering in their garden with their little spades and shooting grouse at Balmoral. Oh, the horror, the horror-made even worse by knowing that Will and Kate are having to lie low. Of course, knowing the media's attention will gravitate anyway toward the young and vibrant, I feel a tinge of sympathy for the sad fate awaiting Charles and Camilla.",queen elizabeth ii,A2905-P,queen Sam,"This critique by Mr. Jacobs is totally lacking in substance. All it says is that there may be some snags, and because of that we should ditch the entire program. Sure, there are snags. I'd like to see a single payer system, but I'm not advocating jumping ship because I didn't get what I wanted. The GOP on the other hand, is screaming bloody murder because we enacted what was basically a Republican designed plan! It is obvious, that they don't want Obamacare to start because when it succeeds they will look even more ridiculous than they do now.",obamacare,A1464-P,obamacare,1,1,19440,10092378,"[[""critique"", ""mr."", ""jacobs"", ""totally"", ""lacking"", ""substance""], [""says"", ""may"", ""snags"", ""ditch"", ""entire"", ""program""], [""sure"", ""snags""], [""'d"", ""like"", ""see"", ""single"", ""payer"", ""system"", ""'m"", ""advocating"", ""jumping"", ""ship"", ""n't"", ""get"", ""wanted""], [""gop"", ""hand"", ""screaming"", ""bloody"", ""murder"", ""enacted"", ""basically"", ""republican"", ""designed"", ""plan""], [""obvious"", ""n't"", ""want"", ""obamacare"", ""start"", ""succeeds"", ""look"", ""even"", ""ridiculous""]]","[[""NN"", ""NNP"", ""NNP"", ""RB"", ""VBG"", ""NN""], [""VBZ"", ""MD"", ""NNS"", ""VB"", ""JJ"", ""NN""], [""UH"", ""NNS""], [""MD"", ""VB"", ""VB"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""VBP"", ""VBG"", ""VBG"", ""NN"", ""RB"", ""VB"", ""VBD""], [""NNP"", ""NN"", ""VBG"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""VBD"", ""RB"", ""NNP"", ""VBN"", ""NN""], [""JJ"", ""RB"", ""VB"", ""NNP"", ""VB"", ""VBZ"", ""VB"", ""RB"", ""JJ""]]",critique mr. jacobs totally lacking substance. says may snags ditch entire program. sure snags. Dan Stackhouse,"P.S.: if there are any doubts about my manliness, consider this. Last night for dinner, I had: two slices of pizza with olives, and plenty of garlic and salt, off of paper plates; a non-lite beer;" and for dessert
post: some chocolate-covered squid (really). Completely without regard to health
new_topic: I do declare.""
label: modern men
column77: p.s.. doubts manliness consider. last night dinner two slices pizza olives plenty garlic salt paper plates non lite beer dessert chocolate covered squid really. completely without regard health calories halitosis. manly declare

author: Dean,"I am a lifelong reader of the NYT and its comments sections are invaluable to me. As others have said, I often learn as much from the comments as I do from the original article;" and I enjoy and appreciate the points of view of other informed readers
post: even those with whom I disagree
ori_topic: without wading through pages of muck. Yes
ori_id: I know the NYT's heavy moderation is time-consuming and expensive -- but I believe it has paid off. I would spend much less time reading the NY Times if it did not have its thoughtfully moderated comments. Personally
new_topic: I think this is a major reason why
label: unlike so many established newspapers
type_idx: the NYT seems to be thriving in today's digital world with its online editions.""
column147: lifelong reader nyt comments sections invaluable. others said often learn much comments original article enjoy appreciate points view informed readers even disagree without wading pages muck. yes know nyt 's heavy moderation time consuming expensive -- believe paid. would spend much less time reading ny times thoughtfully moderated comments. personally think major reason unlike many established newspapers nyt seems thriving today 's digital world online editions

author: Ana V.,"""Nonfiction can be frighteningly raw. While fiction comforts us with the knowledge that actors are delivering lines crafted by writers, reality television offers no protective cover. Here, even lives are at risk. We must face ourselves and each other."" Reality TV shows have become so popular simply because it intrigues us as humans to see how other interact. We watch reality to for entertainment that it has to offer yet is the raw that nothing can seem to conforms us. Its so contradicting with itself that it amuseses us. Reality TV makes us confront with exactly what our society has become. Many say is trash but if is trash then we must reevaluting how our society is today as a whole. If critics seems that reality TV is trash is not worth our time i beg the differ that it is. It opens our eyes of what is out there and the problems we should be dealing with instead of setting them aside to be ignore. No reality TV makes it for us not ignore it anymore but confront it beause we cannot hide behind our lies anymore.",other tv,A2577-P,other tv,1,1,10627,7487326,"[[""nonfiction"", ""frighteningly"", Andrew Beggs,"I agree, owning a cat is a commitment which involves taking on a duty of care. If someone would tolerate mutilating an animal in order to protect their furniture then I don't think they should be having a pet in the first place. Matthew Carnicelli,"While it's true that many unmoderated comments sections can become sewers (the NY Daily News section was an absolute cesspool...), moderated comments sections like those The Times actually make a tremendous contribution to both reader understanding of the issues and our political process. I would also stipulate that allowing anonymous comments can indeed be problematic, and that commentators should be willing to disclose their identity when expressing their opinion - and thus expose themselves to the potential scrutiny that goes along with doing this.",comment sections,A2848-P,comment sections,1,1,8490,18241379,"[[""'s"", ""true"", ""many"", ""unmoderated"", ""comments"", ""sections"", ""become"", ""sewers"", ""ny"", ""daily"", ""news"", ""section"", ""absolute"", ""cesspool"", ""..."", ""moderated"", ""comments"", ""sections"", ""like"", ""times"", ""actually"", ""make"", ""tremendous"", ""contribution"", ""reader"", ""understanding"", ""issues"", ""political"", ""process""], [""would"", ""also"", ""stipulate"", ""allowing"", ""anonymous"", ""comments"", ""indeed"", ""problematic"", ""commentators"", ""willing"", ""disclose"", ""identity"", ""expressing"", ""opinion"", ""thus"", ""expose"", ""potential"", ""scrutiny"", ""goes"", ""along""]]","[[""VBZ"", ""JJ"", ""JJ"", ""JJ"", ""NNS"", ""NNS"", ""VB"", ""NNS"", ""NNP"", ""NNP"", ""NNP"", ""NN"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""NFP"", ""JJ"", ""NNS"", ""NNS"", ""IN"", ""NNP"", ""RB"", ""VBP"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""VB"", ""NN"", ""NNS"", ""JJ"", ""NN""], [""MD"", ""RB"", ""VB"", ""VBG"", ""JJ"", ""NNS"", ""RB"", ""JJ"", ""NNS"", ""JJ"", ""VB"", ""NN"", ""VBG"", ""NN"", ""RB"", ""VB"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""VBZ"", ""RP""]]",'s true many unmoderated comments sections become sewers ny daily news section absolute cesspool ... moderated comments sections like times actually make tremendous contribution reader understanding issues political process. would also stipulate allowing anonymous comments indeed problematic commentators willing disclose identity expressing opinion thus expose potential scrutiny goes along,"[""comment"", ""section""]",comment section,1,0;;;

Kim,"This is why the only subscription I maintain now is to the Times. I used to subscribe to other newspapers but the non moderation drives me crazy. Matt P,"Mr. Lackman says Europe will not agree to end its disastrous austerity policies toward Greece for fear that they will have to do so elsewhere. That's a feature, not a bug. Austerity has been bad for Europe as a whole;" it's led directly to the third recession in 7 years

author: Debbie D,"Voice recognition is not where it needs to be at all, especially when trying to capture back and forth across a big room. Don't have a problem with an audio record also, but have to have text. I know this is not how we are 'supposed' to think about technology, but do we want to end thousands of good paying jobs? Will,"For some reason farmers (and fisherman) view making a profit as a right. Why should the rest of us support them? Farms are no more required for national security than are supermarkets or restaurants. If those businesses can survive in a free market, so can farms. In a time when unemployment is so high and our infrastructure is crumbling, giving money to farmers is disgraceful. The fact that most subsidies actually go to large agro-business and wealthy farmers is even more galling.",farm subsidies,A4642-P,farm subsidies,0,1,9281,2879338,"[[""reason"", ""farmers"", ""fisherman"", ""view"", ""making"", ""profit"", ""right""], [""rest"", ""us"", ""support""], [""farms"", ""required"", ""national"", ""security"", ""supermarkets"", ""restaurants""], [""businesses"", ""survive"", ""free"", ""market"", ""farms""], [""time"", ""unemployment"", ""high"", ""infrastructure"", ""crumbling"", ""giving"", ""money"", ""farmers"", ""disgraceful""], [""fact"", ""subsidies"", ""actually"", ""go"", ""large"", ""agro"", ""business"", ""wealthy"", ""farmers"", ""even"", ""galling""]]","[[""NN"", ""NNS"", ""NN"", ""VBP"", ""VBG"", ""NN"", ""NN""], [""NN"", ""PRP"", ""VBP""], [""NNS"", ""VBN"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""NNS"", ""NNS""], [""NNS"", ""VB"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""NNS""], [""NN"", ""NN"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""VBG"", ""VBG"", ""NN"", ""NNS"", ""JJ""], [""NN"", ""NNS"", ""RB"", ""VBP"", ""JJ"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""JJ"", ""NNS"", ""RB"", ""JJ""]]",reason farmers fisherman view making profit right. rest us support. farms required national security supermarkets restaurants. businesses survive free market farms. time unemployment high infrastructure crumbling giving money farmers disgraceful. fact subsidies actually go large agro business wealthy farmers even galling,"[""farm"", ""subsidy""]",farm subsidy,1,0;;;

Will,"For some reason farmers (and fisherman) view making a profit as a right. Why should the rest of us support them? Emanuel Kataev,"I've been an intern at several places and can say that while there are educational elements to them, interns are mostly given grunt work to assist paid employees. After my experience, I have decided I will never be an intern and/or work for free again. A lot of people are fooled into believing that based on their grades and/or standing in school, there is no other way to get your foot in the door. That is not true. As a mediocre student, I was able to find a paid position where I worked, got paid, and just as well received the same educational value I would have received if I was unpaid. In my opinion, interns should receive minimum wage. Granted, they have no experience, minor if not any qualifications, and generally no practical knowledge. However, they use their limbs and their brains just as any paid employee. This would be most fair, and would certainly boost the United States economy.",unpaid intenship,A490-P,unpaid intenship,0,1,14346,5447530,"[[""'ve"", ""intern"", ""several"", ""places"", ""say"", Raymond,"As an American Latino I do not at all like the separation between ' us ' and everyone else. We are one nation. Why are we so quick to say Latino families should be afforded higher education? How, in this age of political correctness, is that okay? Are we going to run around wearing Brown Pride shirts next? If white folk decided to have ' white only ' forums or ' white only ' college programs that would be labeled racist and exclusionary. We Latinos separate ourselves ENOUGH by insisting on very little to zero assimilation in our communities and on being Latin in everything we say, do, read and watch. We even teach our children to shun away from saying they are Americans like its a bad thing. College is NOT a right. As such, we shouldn't to get a free ride just because we happen to speak Spanish at home. It's an archaic way of thinking and not what the American Dream is supposed to be. I do not support segregation in any form. It creates animosity and we have enough of that already. I don't agree with the all black institutions or the Nedro college fund either.",college,A4672-P,college is not a right,0,2,4008,17282924,"[[""american"", ""latino"", ""like"", ""separation"", ""us"", Barbara,"Declawing is never a reasonable alternative,mutilating cats does not keep them in their homes just check any non kill animal shelter and see how many declawed cats have lost their homes for litterbox avoidance and aggression caused by the pain of those stumps. Note I said non kill shelters, in kill shelters declawed cats are routinely put to death immediately as unrehomeable because they no longer trust human beings and who can blame them? Declawing is despicable and it's people like you who are responsible for the millions of cats living in misery with sore stumps and claw regrowth. Owning a cat is a privilege not a right and if a person can't cope with a clawed cat then they have no business taking one into their home. Des Johnson,"We need an agency like the CIA. If splitting it gives carte blanche to one to group to carry out black ops without oversight, no! More likely, we need to split the Dept. Of Homeland Security, a grotesque organization in which singular organizations like the Secret Service lost their focus. Even more likely, we need a national ethos that dictates the limits of operations by the hard men and ethically challenged who are attracted to violence and torture. How often do we need to say it? The GOP needs to learn to compromise. Otherwise we get a pendulum swinging from one ethos to another, with the result the intelligence and other agents are given too much freedom and too little real moral support.",the c.i.a.,A715-P,the Dave,"One of the useful roles a comment sections can serve: an immediate correction mechanism from the general public when an author is demonstrably wrong on the facts. For example, another news site ran an article decrying the fact that none of the presidential candidates had bothered to pay any attention to New York's public housing projects. Within about 15 minutes of the story being released, commenters were putting up links to stories about Bernie Sanders visiting New York's public housing projects about 10 hours earlier, a rebuttal that many readers might have been unaware of had the comment section not existed. And the New York Times' centralized moderation system isn't the only way to get real legitimate debate going, with evidence and logic being thrown around (along with the occasional entertainment like parody song lyrics or poetry).",comment sections,A2847-P,comment sections,1,1,11160,18243443,"[[""one"", ""useful"", ""roles"", ""comment"", ""sections"", ""serve"", ""immediate"", ""correction"", Bob Garcia,"Rizzo gives us vague generalities about the usefulness of the CIA. Let's turn that around and ask for some demonstrable lists of vital support they have provides over the last two decades. Oh yes, and as a lawyer, Rizzo should be sure to separate the list into legal and illegal support. In other words, let's start from the premise that the CIA has been an irresponsible rogue organization and have them prove otherwise. I know, never going to happen. Our leaders have no will for accountability -- it may be a competition between President Obama and Congress as to which branch of government is less interested!",the c.i.a.,A726-P,the c.i.a.,0,1,11986,13651833,"[[""rizzo"", ""gives"", ""us"", ""vague"", ""generalities"", ""usefulness"", ""cia""], [""let"", ""'s"", ""turn"", ""around"", ""ask"", ""demonstrable"", ""lists"", ""vital"", ""support"", ""provides"", ""last"", ""two"", ""decades""], [""oh"", ""yes"", ""lawyer"", ""rizzo"", ""sure"", ""separate"", ""list"", ""legal"", ""illegal"", ""support""], [""words"", ""let"", ""'s"", ""start"", ""premise"", ""cia"", ""irresponsible"", ""rogue"", ""organization"", ""prove"", ""otherwise""], [""know"", ""never"", ""going"", ""happen""], [""leaders"", ""accountability"", ""--"", ""may"", ""competition"", ""president"", ""obama"", ""congress"", ""branch"", ""government"", ""less"", ""interested""]]","[[""NN"", ""VBZ"", ""PRP"", ""JJ"", ""NNS"", ""NN"", ""NNP""], [""VB"", ""PRP"", ""VB"", ""RB"", ""VB"", ""JJ"", ""NNS"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""VBZ"", ""JJ"", ""CD"", ""NNS""], [""UH"", ""UH"", ""NN"", ""NNP"", ""JJ"", ""VB"", ""NN"", ""JJ"", ""JJ"", ""NN""], [""NNS"", ""VB"", ""PRP"", ""VB"", ""NN"", ""NNP"", ""JJ"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""VB"", ""RB""], [""VBP"", ""RB"", ""VBG"", ""VB""], [""NNS"", ""NN"", "":"", ""MD"", ""NN"", ""NNP"", ""NNP"", ""NNP"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""RBR"", ""JJ""]]",rizzo gives us vague generalities usefulness cia. let 's turn around ask demonstrable lists vital support provides last two decades. oh yes lawyer rizzo sure separate list legal illegal support. words let 's start premise cia irresponsible rogue organization prove otherwise. know never going happen. leaders accountability -- may competition president obama congress branch government less interested,"[""c.i.a""]",c.i.a,0,0;;;

Glendon,"The CIA reminds me by its recent actions of the old joke, ""Military Intelligence is a contradiction in terms."" To the extent that the CIA has become militarized and lawless, (which is the real reason that the prison at Guantanemo was established, so that torture could take place without the oversight of U.S. law) it has become a detriment to the nation, and a blot on the United States' reputation. We should disband the CIA and assign its responsibilities to civilians who will obey the laws and understand the consequences of covert actions to our foreign relations. The State Department should be well up to the task. Faulty intelligence leads to lost wars and continual embarrassment for the politicians who rely on it. The CIA should have no ties to the Department of Defense, so that operations can be unfettered by a military mindset.",the c.i.a.,A725-P,the c.i.a.,0,1,15851,13651841,"[[""cia"", ""reminds"", Look Ahead,"Glad Ms Grace is no longer associated with the Medicaid Commission. But as her credentials for this debate include ""free market ideas for health care reform"", its interesting that she doesn't offer any. Must be one of those ""social welfare"" groups organized to attract tax deductible funds for GOP causes. The Manhattan study focuses only on premiums and not total HC cost. Since the actuarial value is increasing from 45% today to 80% (% of premiums paid in claims) in the individual market, its going to be a better deal by definition. Mr. Roy forgot to mention that. The young male premiums before subsidy go up so much because they are offsetting higher premiums traditionally paid by women in the ""free market"" because they have babies, even though it usually takes two. And younger people are paying more to reduce the age penalty as they get older, much like we do for Medicare. So what's a young high income male without insurance to do (not many of these, BTW) to reduce their premiums? They can buy catastrophic coverage for a small amount to cover major expenses, just as before.",obamacare,A1450-P,obamacare,0,1,8357,10098566,"[[""glad"", ""ms"", ""grace"", ""longer"", John,"Student feedback, in my opinion is a good thing as long as there is mechanism to lift the veil of anonymity when libel is claimed. In some cases, students may seek the easiest path to a degree, while the university strive to maintain a reputation. One area reviews likely address is large differences in difficulty and approaches to the same class. I it as an injustice if two professors teaching the same material give very different grade for the students of similar competence and discipline. This is contrary to the AP system when many thousands of students take the same exam. Ratings may help eliminate this by create an obvious difference in demand when creating schedules.",rate professors,A4745-P,rate professors,1,1,1843,16967564,"[[""student"", ""feedback"", ""opinion"", The cat in the hat,Why are Muslims always attempting to pretend they're victims? Try being a non-Muslim in a majority Muslim nation and you'll see some real victimization. Laura S.,"The greatest treat for my 91 year old dad almost up till he died, was reading the New York Times commentary. He taught architecture and was a liberal type. Every morning he commented to me that he was impressed;" commentary was knowledgable and informative and it took all day. I was glad that he found his very own hang out where people cared about being informed citizens.""
post: comment sections
column77: greatest treat 91 year old dad almost till died reading new york times commentary. taught architecture liberal type. every morning commented impressed commentary knowledgable informative took day. glad found hang people cared informed citizens

author: Maigari,"Germany leaving the Euro now? hardly fesible given the enrmous costs involved. The Greeks, Portuguese and to some extent the Italians have been forced to make sometimes debilitating cuts just to keep the union. If Germany exits, the resulting depression will once again bring to the fore the ultra nationalists in many states and no one can predict the resultant chaos that will inevitably follow. For the time being germany ie well trapped in the euro until the crisis ebbs and then the argument to separate may in all probability ebb away also",germany,A3161-P,germany,0,1,3799,7638928,"[[""germany"", ""leaving"", ""euro""], [""hardly"", ""fesible"", ""given"", ""enrmous"", ""costs"", ""involved""], [""greeks"", ""portuguese"", ""extent"", ""italians"", ""forced"", ""make"", ""sometimes"", ""debilitating"", ""cuts"", ""keep"", ""union""], [""germany"", ""exits"", ""resulting"", ""depression"", ""bring"", ""fore"", ""ultra"", ""nationalists"", ""many"", ""states"", ""one"", ""predict"", ""resultant"", ""chaos"", ""inevitably"", ""follow""], [""time"", ""germany"", ""ie"", ""well"", ""trapped"", ""euro"", ""crisis"", ""ebbs"", ""argument"", ""separate"", ""may"", ""probability"", ""ebb"", ""away"", ""also""]]","[[""NNP"", ""VBG"", ""NNP""], [""RB"", ""JJ"", ""VBN"", ""JJ"", ""NNS"", ""VBN""], [""NNPS"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""NNPS"", ""VBN"", ""VB"", ""RB"", ""VBG"", ""NNS"", ""VB"", ""NN""], [""NNP"", ""NNS"", ""VBG"", ""NN"", ""VB"", ""NN"", ""JJ"", ""NNS"", ""JJ"", ""NNS"", ""NN"", ""VB"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""RB"", ""VB""], [""NN"", ""NN"", ""RB"", ""RB"", ""VBN"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""VBZ"", ""NN"", ""VB"", ""MD"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""RB"", ""RB""]]",germany leaving euro. hardly fesible given enrmous costs involved. greeks portuguese extent italians forced make sometimes debilitating cuts keep union. germany exits resulting depression bring fore ultra nationalists many states one predict resultant chaos inevitably follow. time germany ie well trapped euro crisis ebbs argument separate may probability ebb away also,"[""germany""]",germany,0,1;;;

Yoda,"The new Greek govt must do 2 things. One is to negotiate a decrease (or restructuring to longer payment terms) of its debt. That is the immediate problem. The new Govt. may or may not be able to do this. That will depend on how the negotiations go with the creditors. Simultaneously, and very importantly however, Greece must undergo serious economic reforms. For example the creation of a land registry, a stop to political vote buying by politicians, a stop to corruption, the creation of an apolitical statistical service, a non-pollitcal civil servant based on merit instead of cronyism, etc. Does the new Govt show any signs of this (beyond rheteric)? Absolutely not. There are no signs that a land registry will be created, that merit will be the basis of a civil service, that a non-political statistical service will be created or that an effective tax collection agency will be set up. Hence this latter task will not be accomplished.",greece 's anti-austerity government,A798-P,greece 's anti-austerity government,0,1,4140,13981594,"[[""new"", ""greek"", ""govt"", ""must"", ""2"", Shane Mage,"This reading of the 14th amendment would first of all outlaw all dual citizenship, since to be a citizen of a country means to owe allegiance to it. But it would have no effect at all on any newborn infant who from birth would be subject to a US jurisdiction and would remain so as long as she was in the country, no matter what the nationality or immigration status of her parents!",birthright citizenship,A4204-P,birthright citizenship,1,1,4545,15882141,"[[""reading"", ""14th"", ""amendment"", ""would"", ""first"", ""outlaw"", ""dual"", ""citizenship"", ""since"", ""citizen"", ""country"", ""means"", ""owe"", ""allegiance""], [""would"", ""effect"", ""newborn"", ""infant"", ""birth"", ""would"", ""subject"", ""us"", ""jurisdiction"", ""would"", ""remain"", ""long"", ""country"", ""matter"", ""nationality"", ""immigration"", ""status"", ""parents""]]","[[""NN"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""MD"", ""RB"", ""NN"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""IN"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""VBZ"", ""VB"", ""NN""], [""MD"", ""NN"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""MD"", ""JJ"", ""NNP"", ""NN"", ""MD"", ""VB"", ""RB"", ""NN"", ""RB"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""NNS""]]",reading 14th amendment would first outlaw dual citizenship since citizen country means owe allegiance. would effect newborn infant birth would subject us jurisdiction would remain long country matter nationality immigration status parents,"[""birthright"", ""citizenship""]",birthright citizenship,1,0;;;

Brian,"I seldom read any column or analysis that does not allow comments. I join the others who say they often get more info and insight from the comments than the original piece. Moderating, at this stage in publishing, seems essential to diminish the troll effect. I would suggest a stated policy of allowing only one or two comments per article would also help. One need only go to WaPo to see why. Most comments sections contain over 1,000 posts and are filled with individuals posting scores of comments. Another idea would be to increase moderating and charge a higher subscription rate for the privilege of commenting. One could continue to allow all to read the comments, just charge for writing them. I would be willing to pay a few bucks a month more.",comment sections,A2746-P,comment sections,1,1,12550,18247581,"[[""seldom"", ""read"", ""column"", ""analysis"", ""allow"", ""comments""], hen3ry,"When did having 75% of the students passing a course with a C or better become a good thing? I think that a 75% passing rate is not good. Did anyone work with these students to understand why only 75% of them passed? How much did the 75% who passed understand? Were they able to apply what they had been taught on line? I've taken online courses and they were not well designed, flexible, or conducive to having a discussion. This holds true for a set of courses I took 5 years ago and for several I've taken in the last year. Having an on line course available in conjunction with a live course would be great. Then the students can go over it to see what they've missed, ask questions if that doesn't help, and refer back to it when their notes aren't enough to recall the subject matter to mind. hen3ry,"When did having 75% of the students passing a course with a C or better become a good thing? I think that a 75% passing rate is not good. Terry McKenna,"And then what? Absent genetic testing of all children, we will see a market for US citizen fathers to stand as parent on the birth certificate for mothers without legal status. ACEkin,"I write as professor emeritus from a well-known institute of higher education. For over 4 decades I taught marketing research which is inherently involved in measurement. I know from teaching this subject and conducting research, measurement is a very complex and unforgiving process and is as good ad the instrument and its administration. As much as I believe that good measurement of performance is very valuable to faculty members, I also believe that much of this measurement is done carelessly and unscientifically. Consequently, you are more likely to see extreme results and some that do not make the intended sense at all. One of the best compliments I received from a student was in the form of what he or she must have thought to be highly critical, and I quote: ""The worst teacher I have ever had. He did not teach me anything, I had to read the book myself."" Read it once more if you like and think about it, this is what we call measurement?",rate professors,A4744-P,rate professors,0,1,6329,16967592,"[[""write"", ""professor"", ""emeritus"", ""well"", Daniel Hoffman,"Ryan Radia writes like someone who is a newbie to Android. He could get better informed by following XDA-Developers, AndroidCentral, or a similar group of people who understand Android. Mr. Radia could also visit the PlayStore and look at all the applications, like Titanium Backup, that require root access to function. App Quarantine Pro, would let you lock down crapware so that it does not run down your battery, slow your device, or spy on you. You cannot use sophisticated spyware blockers because that interferes with Google, the device manufacturers and the networks from selling your personal data. Google, the device makers, and the networks, collude to prevent people from actually owning their devices. If they really belonged to us, we would be able to install software to backup them up to an external hard-drive. We would be able to decide which applications to uninstall. We would be able to decide upon the rules applications have to follow when they are on our devices, not the ""take it or leave it"" practices we have at Former Victim of Sexual Abuse,"I learned cursive in grade school back in the 80's and I haven't stopped using it since. It's a skill I am grateful I have. As kids, we took pride in our handwriting...today...I don't think kids know what a pen is. That's sad. I look at some handwriting from pretty high level professionals and it's atrocious. People don't even write whole words anymore. To me, this speaks to standards, which I believe were effectively lowered forever when spellcheck was invented. Soon the question will be asked...do children need to write at all...can't they just text the answers to their teachers? I, for one, look forward to the beautifully handwritten notes I get from friends and remember them much more than emails and text messages. Former Victim of Sexual Abuse,"I learned cursive in grade school back in the 80's and I haven't stopped using it since. It's a skill I am grateful I have. As kids, we took pride in our handwriting...today...I don't think kids know what a pen is. That's sad. I look at some handwriting from pretty high level professionals and it's atrocious. People don't even write whole words anymore. To me, this speaks to standards, which I believe were effectively lowered forever when spellcheck was invented. Soon the question will be asked...do children need to write at all...can't they just text the answers to their teachers? I, for one, look forward to the beautifully handwritten notes I get from friends and remember them much more than emails and text messages. Please, let's not lower the standards on handwriting too.",students,A3692-P,getting away from technology,1,2,10760,8892334,"[[""learned"", ""cursive"", ""grade"", ""school"", ""back"", ""80"", ""'s"", ""n't"", ""stopped"", ""using"", ""since""], [""'s"", ""skill"", ""grateful""], [""kids"", ""took"", ""pride"", ""handwriting"", ""..."", ""today"", ""..."", ""n't"", ""think"", ""kids"", ""know"", ""pen""], [""'s"", ""sad""], [""look"", ""handwriting"", ""pretty"", ""high"", ""level"", ""professionals"", ""'s"", ""atrocious""], [""people"", ""n't"", ""even"", ""write"", ""whole"", ""words"", ""anymore""], [""speaks"", ""standards"", ""believe"", ""effectively"", ""lowered"", ""forever"", ""spellcheck"", ""invented""], [""soon"", ""question"", ""asked"", ""..."", ""children"", ""need"", ""write"", ""..."", ""can't"", ""text"", ""answers"", ""teachers""], [""one"", ""look"", ""forward"", ""beautifully"", ""handwritten"", ""notes"", ""get"", ""friends"", ""remember"", ""much"", ""emails"", ""text"", ""messages""], [""please"", ""let"", ""'s"", ""lower"", ""standards"", ""handwriting""]]","[[""VBD"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""RB"", ""CD"", ""POS"", ""RB"", ""VBN"", ""VBG"", ""RB""], [""VBZ"", ""NN"", ""JJ""], [""NNS"", ""VBD"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""NFP"", ""NN"", "":"", ""RB"", ""VB"", ""NNS"", ""VB"", ""NN""], [""VBZ"", ""JJ""], [""VBP"", ""NN"", ""RB"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""NNS"", ""VBZ"", ""JJ""], [""NNS"", ""RB"", ""RB"", ""VB"", ""JJ"", ""NNS"", ""RB""], [""VBZ"", ""NNS"", ""VBP"", ""RB"", ""VBN"", ""RB"", ""NN"", ""VBN""], [""RB"", ""NN"", ""VBN"", ""NFP"", ""NNS"", ""VB"", ""VB"", ""NFP"", ""MD"", ""VB"", ""NNS"", ""NNS""], [""CD"", ""VB"", ""RB"", ""RB"", ""JJ"", ""NNS"", ""VBP"", ""NNS"", ""VB"", ""RB"", ""NNS"", ""NN"", ""NNS""], [""UH"", ""VB"", ""PRP"", ""VB"", ""NNS"", ""NN""]]",learned cursive grade school back 80 's n't stopped using since. WilliamH,"Odd for me to say this since I am (a) so deeply committed to technology and computers and type super fast (>100wpm), and (b) have really bad handwriting -- but I cannot imagine not writing in cursive. Writing in print is impossible. It is so slow as to be like using a early (not even late) generation dial-up modem. And for me at least, writing does stimulate thinking in a way that nothing else does. I took all my college and law school exams in writing, even though we were allowed to type them. For me at least, not being able to write really really fast would greatly lessen my capabilities. Indeed, I've even thought about taking a short-hand class since my writing is just for me, not anyone else.",students,A3699-P,students,1,1,12426,8892337,"[[""odd"", ""say"", ""since"", ""deeply"", Larry Figdill,"Well stated. This is the essence of what teaching is about, beyond basic preparation of material for the whole class. It's hard to understand why this isn't more obvious to people, especially educated people who have benefited from great teachers in their career. While online tools have much to offer to complement the learning experience when used well, the only reason to see them as a substitute for real teaching is as a major (low quality) cost savings for the masses. And a homogenization of education to serve the needs of big corporate providers of educational materials.",the best way,A2386-P,the best way,1,1,11127,3647415,"[[""well"", ""stated""], [""essence"", ""teaching"", ""beyond"", ""basic"", ""preparation"", ""material"", ""whole"", ""class""], [""'s"", ""hard"", ""understand"", ""n't"", ""obvious"", ""people"", ""especially"", ""educated"", ""people"", ""benefited"", ""great"", ""teachers"", ""career""], [""online"", ""tools"", ""much"", ""offer"", ""complement"", ""learning"", ""experience"", ""used"", ""well"", ""reason"", ""see"", ""substitute"", ""real"", ""teaching"", ""major"", ""low"", ""quality"", ""cost"", ""savings"", ""masses""], [""homogenization"", ""education"", ""serve"", ""needs"", ""big"", ""corporate"", ""providers"", ""educational"", ""materials""]]","[[""UH"", ""VBN""], [""NN"", ""NN"", ""IN"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""JJ"", ""NN""], [""VBZ"", ""JJ"", ""VB"", ""RB"", ""JJ"", ""NNS"", ""RB"", ""VBN"", ""NNS"", ""VBN"", ""JJ"", ""NNS"", ""NN""], [""JJ"", ""NNS"", ""JJ"", ""VB"", ""VB"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""VBN"", ""RB"", ""NN"", ""VB"", ""NN"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""JJ"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""VBP"", ""NNS"", ""NNS""], [""NN"", ""NN"", ""VB"", ""NNS"", ""JJ"", ""JJ"", ""NNS"", ""JJ"", ""NNS""]]",well stated. essence teaching beyond basic preparation material whole class. Roger,"Then why do German voters continue to elect politicians that support the Euro and punish those that don't? They vacation there, they buy their olive oil from them. Roger,"Then why do German voters continue to elect politicians that support the Euro and punish those that don't? Brunella,"Tactile is necessary, along with virtual. Much of the digital landscape, aside from e-books, gets taken out of context, condensed, regurgitated as pull quotes, whether proofread/fact-checked or not. Libraries offer context, community and sensory pleasures that the digital world cannot match, as well as the opportunity to discover long-forgotten or out-of-print gems. Michael Cosgrove,"I disagree. For some of us, such as runners who go out in the sweltering heat for a long distance run in the desert, replenishing the salt and electrolytes lost during the run is a matter of health and recovery, not merely a flavoring option. I can understand that sedentary people and some chefs might blanch when the see me salting my food at a restaurant. Nancy Lederman,"Count me a longtime fan of the 14th Amendment of the US Constitution, for its breadth and scope that encompasses the greatest of American values: not just defining citizenship, but setting forth states' obligations, due process, equal protection of the laws, This was the Amendment that required the states to follow the Bill of Rights. Brown v Board of Education, civil rights laws, privacy rulings, women's rights, gay rights, disability protections, they all flow from the 14th. Cflapjack,Back in the day I recall getting my midterm and paper back while taking the final. The prof did not give me my paper during the exam because I had done poorly and he did not want me to lose my concentration. Nice guy. When I finally got the paper from him and he told me how bad it was I had to hold my tongue because he could still have failed me. Of course if I had known I was doing poorly in the class I would have gone to his office and asked him how I could improve. Ask what I was doing wrong. He had done nothing wrong and it was common for profs to do the minimum of work. Anita,"I would no more declaw a cat than fly to the moon on gossamer wings! There's another option, which some consider to be more humane, and that is to cut the muscles or whatever that allow the cat to retract its claws. They just flop in or out, depending on the position of the cat. PLEASE explain to me why this form of torture is more humane than declawing. I could never maim, hurt, torture or kill any animal. My cat is a strictly indoor creature, she has all of her claws and a nice big scratching post/cat tree. She has NEVER ONCE scratched on anything but that. I taught her to do that. It is NOT impossible to train a cat!",your cat,A842-P,your cat,1,1,16737,17020896,"[[""would"", ""declaw"", ""cat"", ""fly"", ""moon"", ""gossamer"", ""wings""], [""'s"", ""another"", ""option"", ""consider"", ""humane"", ""cut"", ""muscles"", ""whatever"", ""allow"", ""cat"", ""retract"", ""claws""], [""flop"", ""depending"", ""position"", ""cat""], [""please"", ""explain"", ""form"", ""torture"", ""humane"", ""declawing""], [""could"", ""never"", ""maim"", ""hurt"", ""torture"", ""kill"", ""animal""], [""cat"", ""strictly"", ""indoor"", ""creature"", ""claws"", ""nice"", ""big"", ""scratching"", ""post"", ""cat"", ""tree""], [""never"", ""scratched"", ""anything""], [""taught""], [""impossible"", ""train"", ""cat""]]","[[""MD"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""VB"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""NNS""], [""VBZ"", ""DT"", ""NN"", ""VBP"", ""JJ"", ""VB"", ""NNS"", ""WDT"", ""VBP"", ""NN"", ""VB"", ""NN""], [""VBP"", ""VBG"", ""NN"", ""NN""], [""UH"", ""VB"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""JJ"", ""VBG""], [""MD"", ""RB"", ""VB"", ""VBN"", ""NN"", ""VBP"", ""NN""], [""NN"", ""RB"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""JJ"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""NN""], [""RB"", ""VBN"", ""NN""], [""VBD""], [""JJ"", ""VB"", ""NN""]]",would declaw cat fly moon gossamer wings. George,"Privatization of state asserts means that German businessmen can buy those asserts at a fraction of their real value and make Greece a German colony. Lachman has served the interests of the world's financial elites whose motto (Adam Smith, bk 3) is ""everything for ourselves and nothing for other people."" Those German businessmen and firms spent hundreds of millions of euros bribing Greek officials to buy German weapons including a set of submarines that never went to sea and are now rusting ashore--Merkel's masters want them paid for though the debt be odious. A major NY bank enabled a Greek government to disguise huge borrowings as investments; those debts too are odious. There's a story: Merkel went to Greece;" the customs official asked """"Nationality
post: " Merkel answered """"German."""" """"Occupation"""" asked the customs officer
ori_id: I'm just here for the weekend.""""Lachman warns """"leaving the euro would almost surely result in a massive run on the Greek banks
new_topic: which would plunge the country into economic and financial chaos."""" Where does he think Greece is now? Oh yes
label: reparations for the German occupation of Greece during WWII?""

author: Responsible Bob,"The pathway to a career in medicine is designed to benefit specific areas of medicine. To be considered for admission to medical school, candidates must spend significant time and effort on research. This results in substantial free labor for tens of thousands of researchers. Also this effort is focused on research rather than more specifically to areas such as serving the community, which has a lesser role. International medical school graduates also spend months and sometimes longer demonstrating their skills to obtain a residency position. This is another area that can be abused as the stakes are high and there are few protections against abuses. Health professional associations and corporations preparing candidates for standardized tests have a great design that benefits them well, but fails to deliver the health professionals needed.",college students,A495-P,college students,1,1,5455,5445604,"[[""pathway"", ""career"", ""medicine"", ""designed"", ""benefit"", ""specific"", ""areas"", ""medicine""], [""considered"", Old Doc,"The ACA is what we have and what we were able to generate. While it is far from perfect and single-payer would likely be better, we need to try and make it work. Obama should get some credit for making any in-roads in this nasty, contentious climate. And older healthcare advancements came together in piece-meal improvements so there is reason to hope we can move towards single-payer, or least incremental improvement and coverage.",obamacare,A1445-P,obamacare,1,1,8191,10096616,"[[""aca"", ""able"", ""generate""], [""far"", ""perfect"", ""single"", ""payer"", ""would"", ""likely"", ""better"", ""need"", ""try"", ""make"", ""work""], [""obama"", ""get"", ""credit"", ""making"", ""roads"", ""nasty"", ""contentious"", ""climate""], [""older"", ""healthcare"", ""advancements"", ""came"", ""together"", ""piece"", ""meal"", ""improvements"", ""reason"", ""hope"", ""move"", ""towards"", ""single"", ""payer"", ""least"", ""incremental"", ""improvement"", ""coverage""]]","[[""NN"", ""JJ"", ""VB""], [""RB"", ""JJ"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""MD"", ""RB"", ""JJR"", ""VBP"", ""VB"", ""VB"", ""VB""], [""NNP"", ""VB"", ""NN"", ""VBG"", ""NNS"", ""JJ"", ""JJ"", ""NN""], [""JJR"", ""NN"", ""NNS"", ""VBD"", ""RB"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""NNS"", ""NN"", ""VB"", ""VB"", ""IN"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""JJS"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""NN""]]",aca able generate. far perfect single payer would likely better need try make work. obama get credit making roads nasty contentious climate. older healthcare advancements came together piece meal improvements reason hope move towards single payer least incremental improvement coverage,"[""obamacare""]",obamacare,1,0;;;

DCBarrister,Kaiser Permanente signs Bernard J. Tyson's checks. So of course he's down with Obamacare. Getting out of the exchanges altogether (not all together) takes millions out of Kaiser's pockets and profits. So I am stunned to see a Kaiser official pleading with us to keep the ACA. Not.,obamacare,A4918-P,obamacare,0,1,12326,19585001,"[[""kaiser"", ""permanente"", ""signs"", ""bernard"", ""j."", ""tyson"", ""'s"", ""checks""], [""course"", ""'s"", ""obamacare""], [""getting"", ""exchanges"", ""altogether"", ""together"", ""takes"", ""millions"", ""kaiser"", ""'s"", ""pockets"", ""profits""], [""stunned"", ""see"", ""kaiser"", ""official"", ""pleading"", ""us"", ""keep"", ""aca""]]","[[""NNP"", ""NNP"", ""VBZ"", ""NNP"", ""NNP"", ""NNP"", ""POS"", ""NNS""], [""NN"", ""VBZ"", ""NNP""], [""VBG"", ""NNS"", ""RB"", ""RB"", ""VBZ"", ""NNS"", ""NNP"", ""POS"", ""NNS"", ""NNS""], [""JJ"", ""VB"", ""NNP"", ""NN"", ""VBG"", ""PRP"", ""VB"", ""NN""]]",kaiser permanente signs bernard j. tyson 's checks. course 's obamacare. getting exchanges altogether together takes millions kaiser 's pockets profits. stunned see kaiser official pleading us keep aca,"[""obamacare""]",obamacare,1,1;;;

Johnny Comelately,"Shutting down comments sections forces discussion outside of view. It is far better and safer to know the awful truth than to have it hidden from you, to spring up some day fully formed in an unstoppable attack on our carefully tended, walled in and blindfolded world. Than is not to say that some measure of civil discourse rules should not be adopted and enforced, they should. That raises the cost of tending to the comment section, unfortunately. Robots are getting smarter and at some point will take over that job. At such point, they can be used to create the very walls I would worry about - hiding the truth from us again, but this time not because of a simple exclusive wall against free comment. Instead because the robot algorithm may not be able to distinguish some important and ugly truth from an ad hominem attack, giving this more careful wall a small but important factual bias that can no longer open our eyes.",comment sections,A2781-P,comment sections,1,1,4446,18378733,"[[""shutting"", ""comments"", ""sections"", ""forces"", ""discussion"", ""outside"", ""view""], [""far"", lefty442,"I don't think comments sections have failed; the media have failed. I see several things happening; - first
post: the fat cats who control these things (the press
ori_id: etc.) don't want to be publicly embarrassed by well-written
new_topic: cogent counter arguments;" and two
label: they have found out that they can't hire editors to handle the volume for thirty cents a day. The sheer volume itself is an indicator of how deep the sense of abandonment is among the hoi polloi.""
type_idx: comment sections
column110: n't think comments sections failed media failed. see several things happening first fat cats control things press newsletters etc. n't want publicly embarrassed well written cogent counter arguments two found ca n't hire editors handle volume thirty cents day. sheer volume indicator deep sense abandonment among hoi polloi

author: Tim McCoy,"Mr. Wolf sounds as if he would have castigated Mark Twain, and George Sand for using pseudonyms. The fictitious nom de plume is an old and venerable way for writers to express themselves. The actual solution is the one the New York Times employs. Editing irrational or vitriolic commentary, rather than publishing everything, afraid of offending a subscriber here and there if they don't. Instead of threatening to throw out the baby with the bathwater as an alternative, or subjecting the commentariat to TSA type scrutiny before allowing our opinions to be published.",comment sections,A2770-P,comment sections,0,1,4979,18247674,"[[""mr."", ""wolf"", ""sounds"", ""would"", ""castigated"", ""mark"", ""twain"", ""george"", ""sand"", ""using"", ""pseudonyms""], [""fictitious"", ""nom"", ""de"", ""plume"", ""old"", ""venerable"", ""way"", ""writers"", ""express""], [""actual"", ""solution"", ""one"", ""new"", ""york"", ""times"", ""employs""], [""editing"", ""irrational"", ""vitriolic"", ""commentary"", ""rather"", ""publishing"", ""everything"", ""afraid"", ""offending"", ""subscriber"", ""n't""], [""instead"", ""threatening"", ""throw"", ""baby"", ""bathwater"", ""alternative"", ""subjecting"", ""commentariat"", ""tsa"", ""type"", ""scrutiny"", ""allowing"", ""opinions"", ""published""]]","[[""NNP"", ""NNP"", ""VBZ"", ""MD"", ""VBN"", ""NNP"", ""NNP"", ""NNP"", ""NNP"", ""VBG"", ""NNS""], [""JJ"", ""NN"", ""FW"", ""NN"", ""JJ"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""NNS"", ""VB""], [""JJ"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""NNP"", ""NNP"", ""NNP"", ""VBZ""], [""NN"", ""JJ"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""RB"", ""VBG"", ""NN"", ""JJ"", ""VBG"", ""NN"", ""RB""], [""RB"", ""VBG"", ""VB"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""VBG"", ""NN"", ""NNP"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""VBG"", ""NNS"", ""VBN""]]",mr. wolf sounds would castigated mark twain george sand using pseudonyms. fictitious nom de plume old venerable way writers express. actual solution one new york times employs. editing irrational vitriolic commentary rather publishing everything afraid offending subscriber n't. instead threatening throw baby bathwater alternative subjecting commentariat tsa type scrutiny allowing opinions published,"[""comment"", ""section""]",comment section,1,0;;;

Dstaszak,"Look, there are issues to be debateed. Do we need as much brick and mortaror public shelf space as we have? I use libraries a lot. I download audible books frequently, but I don't use my local northern NY library system to do it, I use the NY City Library. If I do want a book I locate it on Amazon (since its presentation of the book: description, professional and reader reviews is much better than the libraries) then I order it (on-line) from my local library system. When I get the e-mail notice that the book is ready I finally pay a visit to my library to pick the book up. Using this process I wonder why my library has publically displayed bookshelves at all.",libraries,A1613-P,libraries,2,4,21854,7950351,"[[""look"", ""issues"", ""debateed""], [""need"", ""much"", Dstaszak,"Look, there are issues to be debateed. Do we need as much brick and mortaror public shelf space as we have? I use libraries a lot. I download audible books frequently, but I don't use my local northern NY library system to do it, I use the NY City Library. If I do want a book I locate it on Amazon (since its presentation of the book: description, professional and reader reviews is much better than the libraries) then I order it (on-line) from my local library system. When I get the e-mail notice that the book is ready I finally pay a visit to my library to pick the book up. angela,"I have a salt sensitivity and have not been able to eat some foods at prepared by the chef. I use just the right amount of salt at home to season dishes. It's a necessary seasoning in most dishes, it just doesn't need to be used in excess. Guess my message is: put those salt shakers on the table for those who enjoy extra salt on their dishes. Please don't have a heavy hand in the kitchen....I'd like to be able to enjoy what I order.",a place at the table,A1782-P,salty food,2,4,21856,9947157,"[[""salt"", ""sensitivity"", ""able"", ""eat"", ""foods"", ""prepared"", ""chef""], [""use"", ""right"", ""amount"", ""salt"", ""home"", ""season"", ""dishes""], [""'s"", ""necessary"", ""seasoning"", ""dishes"", ""n't"", ""need"", ""used"", ""excess""], [""guess"", ""message"", ""put"", ""salt"", ""shakers"", ""table"", ""enjoy"", ""extra"", ""salt"", ""dishes""], [""please"", ""n't"", ""heavy"", ""hand"", ""kitchen"", ""...."", ""i'd"", ""like"", ""able"", ""enjoy"", ""order""]]","[[""NN"", ""NN"", ""JJ"", ""VB"", ""NNS"", ""VBN"", ""NN""], [""VBP"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""NNS""], [""VBZ"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""NNS"", ""RB"", ""VB"", ""VBN"", ""NN""], [""VB"", ""NN"", ""VB"", ""NN"", ""NNS"", ""NN"", ""VBP"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""NNS""], [""UH"", ""RB"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""."", ""NNS"", ""VBP"", ""JJ"", ""VB"", ""VBP""]]",salt sensitivity able eat foods prepared chef. use right amount salt home season dishes. Carole,"I have lived in many cities in the U.S. and in Europe. One of the first things I did with each move was obtain a local library card. At present I have access to both a county library and a nearby city's facility. Both libraries are always crowded with people when I visit them, many using the free computer services, some reading out of town newspapers, others browsing in the video and recorded book section. In my community, the libraries also provide free access to private community rooms where people can meet for many different reasons. Finally, my computer is great, but when I want to relax and read I want a good old fashioned book. Libraries are wonderful places and we need them.",libraries,A1612-P,libraries,2,4,21857,7950363,"[[""lived"", ""many"", ""cities"", ""u.s."", ""europe""], [""one"", ""first"", ""things"", ""move"", sammy zoso,"America will never be a truly great country until health care is provided for all for little to no cost. We pay for public education whether we want to or not, we pay for wars that cost trillions. The U.S. can afford health care for all. Just do it.",obamacare,A4916-P,obamacare,2,4,21858,19585052,"[[""america"", ""never"", ""truly"", ""great"", ""country"", ""health"", ""care"", ""provided"", ""little"", ""cost""], [""pay"", ""public"", ""education"", ""whether"", ""want"", ""pay"", ""wars"", ""cost"", ""trillions""], [""u.s."", ""afford"", ""health"", ""care""]]","[[""NNP"", ""RB"", ""RB"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""VBN"", ""JJ"", ""NN""], [""VBP"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""IN"", ""VBP"", ""VBP"", ""NNS"", ""VBP"", ""NNS""], [""NNP"", ""VB"", ""NN"", ""NN""]]",america never truly great country health care provided little cost. pay public education whether want pay wars cost trillions. u.s. afford health care,"[""c.i.a""]",c.i.a,0,0;;;

Dave,"Real names don't really help. As many other commenters have pointed out, they actually make it easier for online harassment to turn into offline harassment. What does make a difference is long-term accountability. Have pseudonyms tied to an email account that has to be verified periodically (e.g. once a year), and give pseudonyms a reputation score based on moderation (either by paid moderators as the Times does, or by other readers). Those with a high reputation score get perks like their comments being shown earlier, while those with a low reputation score get demoted to the bottom sections that almost nobody sees. That helps clear out the trolls or at least make them invisible.",comment sections,A2780-P,comment sections,2,4,21859,18243621,"[[""real"", ""names"", ""n't"", ""really"", ""help""], [""many"", Dave,"Real names don't really help. As many other commenters have pointed out, they actually make it easier for online harassment to turn into offline harassment. What does make a difference is long-term accountability. Have pseudonyms tied to an email account that has to be verified periodically (e.g. once a year), and give pseudonyms a reputation score based on moderation (either by paid moderators as the Times does, or by other readers). Those with a high reputation score get perks like their comments being shown earlier, while those with a low reputation score get demoted to the bottom sections that almost nobody sees. That helps clear out the trolls or at least make them invisible.",comment sections,A2780-P,online pseudonyms,2,4,21860,18243621,"[[""real"", ""names"", ""n't"", ""really"", ""help""], [""many"", The Semi-Child,"Interesting article. Is Amazon trying for a monopoly on publishing as well? For a writer (like myself) the opportunity of Amazon is the most appealing in regards to finacial benefits. Publishing companies demand, in my opinion, a ridiculous about of royalties. Amazon lets the author keep almost all of the royalties and also the money. The only downside would have to be advertisment and publicity. Publishing companies get the word out far. Amazon pretting much leaves you on your own. So, depending on how good your book is, the profit could fluctuate in each circumstance. If the book is good, I'd publish it through Amazon. If the book was semi-good, I'd go to a publisher. Simple. Lenders made a mistake in this evil bargain and need to pay for their mistakes. Kate,"Several years ago when I was working with a Christian NGO in a largely Muslim area of Northern Kenya I asked a female colleague why she covered her head completely in the same way as Muslim women. She was surprised at my question and responded that it was a sign that she was a mature married woman. This gave me a new perspective on a symbol I had always seen as a sign of strict adherence to Islam. I later watched an interview with a young woman barber in Indonesia, where most Muslims are highly tolerant of other faiths (five are officially recognized by the government) and virtually all Muslim women wear the local style of hijab. When she was asked how she reconciled her profession with Muslim restrictions on contact with men, she replied in a matter of fact way that if she followed this rule she wouldn't be able to work and support her small daughter, and that wouldn't be good for anyone. One can only hope for a world where common sense prevails over the cultural loadings attached to these symbolic acts.",non-muslims,A2616-P,non-muslims,2,4,21873,17139799,"[[""several"", ""years"", Janos Marton,"I can't believe this is a serious topic of debate. I am less than a decade out of college, and certainly had access to Google when I was writing research papers, but no quality college-level research paper can be done without consulting at least several thorough books. If anything, such research papers are more critical now than ever, because people of all ages (not just young people) tend to defer to Wikipedia and other such sites as conventional wisdom, when in fact they are often simplistic accounts of complicated questions.",a useful excercise for college students,A2728-P,google,2,4,21874,4425815,"[[""ca"", ""n't"", ""believe"", ""serious"", ""topic"", ""debate""], [""less"", ""decade"", ""college"", ""certainly"", ""access"", ""google"", ""writing"", ""research"", ""papers"", ""quality"", ""college"", ""level"", ""research"", ""paper"", ""done"", ""without"", ""consulting"", ""least"", ""several"", ""thorough"", ""books""], [""anything"", ""research"", ""papers"", ""critical"", ""ever"", ""people"", ""ages"", ""young"", ""people"", ""tend"", ""defer"", ""wikipedia"", ""sites"", ""conventional"", ""wisdom"", ""fact"", ""often"", ""simplistic"", ""accounts"", ""complicated"", ""questions""]]","[[""MD"", ""RB"", ""VB"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""NN""], [""JJR"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""RB"", ""NN"", ""NNP"", ""VBG"", ""NN"", ""NNS"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""VBN"", ""IN"", ""VBG"", ""RBS"", ""JJ"", ""JJ"", ""NNS""], [""NN"", ""NN"", ""NNS"", ""JJ"", ""RB"", ""NNS"", ""NNS"", ""JJ"", ""NNS"", ""VBP"", ""VB"", ""NNP"", ""NNS"", ""JJ"", ""NN"", ""NN"", ""RB"", ""JJ"", ""NNS"", ""JJ"", ""NNS""]]",ca n't believe serious topic debate. less decade college certainly access google writing research papers quality college level research paper done without consulting least several thorough books. anything research papers critical ever people ages young people tend defer wikipedia sites conventional wisdom fact often simplistic accounts complicated questions,"[""best"", ""way"", ""teach""]",best way teach,0,0;;;

Ian N,"While do like the 99 cent rack on my kindle book store, there's a 50/50 chance that what I look at is self-published because before digital publishing, no one would touch it- and for good reason. A good amount of it is really really bad. So that said, publishers offer the value added-ness, if you will, but setting a standard that makes for an enjoyable read. zzz05,"It works like this: 1) Read headline. 2) Skim first paragraph (optional) 3) Access fixed mental sound byte of some fanatical pet obsession which has slight relevance to minor side note of headline 4) Pen rant advocating said fixed opinion as absolute truth; include sound bytes cribbed verbatim from major opinion leaders with identical opinion;" make sure to exclude any external support
post: evidence
new_topic: links
label: etc. 5) Await reply from equally fanatical reader with completely opposite opinion 6) Repeat rant
type_idx: including extensive insults to all who disagree.""

author: NYer,"My take away lesson from these years of ACA is that we were sold a political promise that like too many was a lie. The Republicans dont have to raise their little finger for this program to fail, it will die of its own losses. Where are the number guys and what do they say about it now, the guys who were touting the program for Mr. Obama? Its a wonderful warm and fuzzy notion to fund healthcare for everyone, and in countries that pay their doctors around 50,000 a year and drugs aren't outrageous etc etc, it may be feasible, but thats not the USA. Check out how much money the drug companies pay our politicians for example. Those tens of millions of dollars comes from the citizens and their insurance in an endless cycle of financial and political imbalance that is always spiraling towards that me,"Obesity is NOT a ""life-style choice."" I have not eaten in a fast food restaurant in over 5 years. I eat no sugar at all -- no baked goods, no candy, no sodas, no jam or honey, no syrup (let alone ""a pound of double stuff Oreos every day""). I eat no red meat -- just fish and lean, skinless poultry. I eat no flour, just whole grains. I eat fresh leafy vegetables and fruits. I eat very little dairy. I limit my calories to between 1500 and 1800 a day. I exercise. And yet, at 5' 7"", I weigh 215 pounds, and have for many years. Those of you who accuse me of a lack of ""self-discipline"" or of ""gluttony"" are ignorant bigots who should be ashamed of yourselves.",legislation,A5021-P,fast food,2,4,21880,4970613,"[[""obesity"", David Bartlett,"Today's hyper-enhanced CGI extravaganzas are not movies, they are video games, where the effects themselves are the featured attraction. It is sensory overload-----pacing, story, character development take a back seat to this new aesthetic. One can easily imagine some twenty- or thirty-something director, succored from birth on the slash-and-burn intensity of video games----and in the case of the very youngest in Hollywood, on MOVIES that have already been styled on such games-----working themselves into a frenzy on a computer, overdosing on special-effects software and whiz-bang CGI. One even imagines that it is the CGI that comes first------waking up in the middle of the night with an 'Oh, wow, that would be AWESOME!' kind of idea, they then build a movie around it only afterward. It is a new language, a new vernacular, of the filmmakers art. Whether anyone but the youngest speak this tongue is a moot point. As the saying goes, if you have to ask, you can't afford it. In this case, if you don't 'get' this new sensibility, you're not relevant in the first place.",computer-generated imagery,A516-P,computer-generated imagery,2,4,21881,8470645,"[[""today"", ""'s"", Susan D.,"I would add that cursive is easier for students with certain disabilities to use because they are not constantly stopping and starting. Ajit,"Restricting access is essential since the world population has exploded and the a significant fraction of the National Park visitors are foreigners. The last time I hiked to the top of Half Dome in 2006, it was an awful experience with people falling over each other like in a shopping mall. Same with the hike to Cloud's Rest. I'm glad they introduced the lottery system for Half Dome. If folks really care about spending time in these precious places, they should have to make the early reservations for the most crowded places. I know we live in an instant gratification society, but we got to draw the line somewhere.
